Data.lessonPreface: This unit is designed for upper level high school and intro undergrad. However, the first two lessons/steps could easily be taught at the middle school level.

lessons.title: Define the Problem
lessons.preface: Students self-reflect and draw mind maps to identify a product in their lives that could be more interesting, sustainable, or functional.

itemList.itemDescription: Optional graphical organizer for students to summarize each step.

lessons.title: Biologize the Problem
lessons.preface: Students find a functional bridge to biology. They use field guides, AI chatbots, and other resources to find adaptations that are analogous to the design challenge they have set for themselves.

lessons.title: Select a Biological Model
lessons.preface: Once they have a short list of potential biological inspirations, they must choose one based on how likely they think it is to translate to real world solutions.

itemList.itemDescription: Optional graphical organizer for students to summarize each step.

lessons.title: Propose Bioinspired Solutions
lessons.preface: Students summarize their work with a one-page graphic organizer. Teachers will decide if they should also present this as a pitch to the class.

itemList.itemDescription: Optional graphical organizer for students to summarize each step.

lessons.title: Evaluate
lessons.preface: If desired, students can incorporate feedback into further refinement of their redesign proposals.

itemList.itemDescription: Optional graphical organizer for students to summarize each step.

lesson.lsnPreface: Students self-reflect and draw mind maps to identify a product in their lives that could be more interesting, sustainable, or functional.
learningObj: Create mind maps to ideate, reflect, and identify a problem with a product or technology.
Recognize that biological evolution has resulted in all kinds of amazing solutions that can provide inspiration to solve realworld problems.
Define a problem with an existing product.

lsnPrep.prepQuickDescription: Assemble larger sheets of paper and colored pencils. Open and review slideshow.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Students will watch a short, 4-minute trailer that outlines the steps of the bioinspired design process.
steps.Vocab: - **Bioinspired Design:**  process of designing solutions that take inspiration from organismal adaptations
steps.TeachingTips: You might decide to show this overview [▶ Borrowing Brilliance from Biology: The Future of Design](https://drive.google.com/file/d/14UKNtxaQRV_MAe4gtc9uO5oRLjqzaJ_Q/preview) during a prior lesson in order to give more time for brainstorming.

steps.StepQuickDescription: With guidance from videos, students will learn how to engage in mind-mapping to identify a product they would like to redesign.
steps.TeachingTips: This lesson will toggle between [▶ Changing the world starts with defining a problem](https://drive.google.com/file/d/19yPDFdTL1GKf7gs18LJ1iT6kw5MgC4MA/preview) and [▶ Kickstart innovation with a mind map](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1H7js0EClx4d59MfU28GcLz-Hi3sqX4pX/preview) to guide students during brainstorming.

steps.StepQuickDescription: By the end of this step, students will clearly define their problem statement.

lsnExt.itemDescription: For making mind maps easily. Free for education.

lsnExt.itemTitle: High Speed Train Inspired by the Kingfisher
lsnExt.itemDescription: This article from AskNature provides more information for students to learn about the bioinspired design for Japan's JR-West railway company.

lesson.lsnPreface: Students find a functional bridge to biology. They use field guides, AI chatbots, and other resources to find adaptations that are analogous to the design challenge they have set for themselves.
learningObj: Use technology, such as AI chatbots, as well as resources like field guides to identify functions in biology that are analogous to an engineering/design problem.
Understand the biological term 'trait' and accurately connect organismal traits to design/engineering analogs. (e.g. fish caudal fin= boat propeller)

lsnPrep.prepQuickDescription: Print out L2 worksheets and open slideshow.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Invite students to share their problem statements and/or other takeaways from the previous step.

steps.StepTitle: Translate the Problem into Abstract Functions
steps.StepQuickDescription: With video guidance, students will learn how to abstractify their problem statement into functions.
steps.Vocab: - **Function:**  serves as the bridge between engineering and biology.
steps.TeachingTips: This lesson relies on [▶ How to search biology for engineering solutions](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1QSVme9bGrAOqV8g2pmvF-AfUvSLlHJkI/view?usp=sharing) which explains how to biologize the problem. Students are encouraged to use [➚ Biologize Student Worksheet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1L4yOQqcPAo43cFddptioY6rRMTFdOV2c9ZzVaYIXb5k/edit?usp=drive_link) to track their work during this step.

steps.StepQuickDescription: Students will conduct exploratory research to find organisms or traits that align with their desired functions.
steps.TeachingTips: Helpful research resources and tips can be found on [➚ Biologize Student Worksheet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1L4yOQqcPAo43cFddptioY6rRMTFdOV2c9ZzVaYIXb5k/edit?usp=drive_link).

steps.StepQuickDescription: By the end of this step, students will define several "what if" statements to explore further.

lsnExt.itemDescription: A useful AI chatbot that can really help students discover biological models, synonyms for their design problems, and identify analogous biology terms. Importantly, Perplexity shows links to backup claims, as many chatbots can hallucinate.
A library of examples of biomimicry and bioinspired design from the Biomimicry Institute.
A helpful research tool, particularly if students know nothing about an organism and want to start with general inquiry.
A great way for students to dive into real research articles. Be sure to show them how to click "All X versions" for an article to find free PDFs which are sometimes available.

lesson.lsnPreface: Once they have a short list of potential biological inspirations, they must choose one based on how likely they think it is to translate to real world solutions.
learningObj: Evaluate the pros/cons, and tradeoffs between different biological models to select one design inspiration.
Propose a bioinspired (re)design solution to address problems with an existing product.
